facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 28 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 28 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 21, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 811 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 21, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 811 of 1953. 1264 Ranadeb Chaudhury and P. K. Chatterjee, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 is one of the past directors of the Bank of Commerce Ltd., now in liquidation.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 1 is One of the past directors of the Bank of Commerce Ltd., number in liquidation and appellant No. 2 was its Managing Director.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 was the Managing Director of the Bank of Commerce Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: in liquidation and appellant No. 2 was its Managing Director. The Bank was ordered to be wound up by the High Court of Calcutta on August 7, 1950, and one G. Dutt, Bar-at-law was appointed its Official Liquidator

facts.text: The Bank of Commerce Ltd. was ordered to be wound up by the High Court of Calcutta on August 7, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank was ordered to be wound up by the High Court of Calcutta on August 7, 1950, and one G. Dutt, Bar-at-law was appointed its Official Liquidator but on September 7, 1950, the Official Receiver

facts.text: G. Dutt, Bar-at-law was appointed Official Liquidator of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: one G. Dutt, Bar-at-law was appointed its Official Liquidator but on September 7, 1950, the Official Receiver was appointed in place of Dutt. On July 23, 1952, respondent No. 1 filed in Court of the Presidency Magistrate a companyplaint

facts.text: Official Receiver was appointed in place of G. Dutt as Official Liquidator on September 7, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: but on September 7, 1950, the Official Receiver was appointed in place of Dutt. On July 23, 1952, respondent No. 1 filed in Court of the Presidency Magistrate a companyplaint against the appellant under ss. 120B, 406, 467, 477A, Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed a complaint against the appellants in the Court of the Presidency Magistrate on July 23, 1952 under sections 120B, 406, 467, 477A IPC and 182A of the Indian Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: On July 23, 1952, respondent No. 1 filed in Court of the Presidency Magistrate a companyplaint against the appellant under ss. 120B, 406, 467, 477A, Indian Penal Code and 182A of the Indian Companies Act and stated that he was doing so under the authority

facts.text: The complaint was filed under the authority of the official liquidator who had obtained directions of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and stated that he was doing so under the authority of the official liquidator and the official liquidator had obtained the directions of the High Court to file the companyplaint. On May 5, 1953, the appellant applied to the I-residency Magistrate

facts.text: Appellants applied to the Presidency Magistrate for dismissal of the complaint on May 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On May 5, 1953, the appellant applied to the I-residency Magistrate for dismissal of the companyplaint as being without the sanction of the Company Judge and therefore the official liquidator in his official capacity

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate dismissed the application on June 13, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: This application was dismissed by the Presidency Magistrate on June 13, 1953. The appellant then applied to the High Court for quashing the criminal proceedings on the ground that the prosecution

facts.text: Appellants applied to Calcutta High Court to quash the criminal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for quashing the criminal proceedings on the ground that the prosecution was ab initio void because of the absence of prior direction judicially given by the High Court under s. 237 1  of the Indian Companies Act.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court discharged the rule against appellants on June 21, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found against the appellants and discharged the rule. The learned Chief Justice held that the provisions of s. 237 1  are numberbar to a prosecution by the liquidator that under s. 237 1  there is numberhing

facts.text: Bachawat J. made an order on January 15, 1951 under s.179 giving liberty to official liquidator to institute proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the official liquidator Bachawat J. an January 15, 1951, made an order which must be taken to be one under s. 179. In this order it was said And it is further ordered that the said applicant be at liberty

facts.text: Bannerji J. made an order on July 22, 1952 under s.237(1) giving liberty to official liquidator to take civil or criminal proceedings based on report of Jasoda Dulal Adhikary and affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: On July 22, 1952, the official liquidator obtained the order from Bannerji J. which the High Court has held, and in our opinion rightly, to be an order under s. 237 1  of the Indian Companies Act. This order said It is ordered

facts.text: Appellants took an appeal against the order of Company Judge dated July 22, 1952, which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the companyplaint the appellants took an appeal against the order of the Company Judge dated July 22, 1952, but it was dismissed on the objection taken by the liquidator that it was an administrative order

facts.text: Official liquidator took out misfeasance proceedings under s.235 on August 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On August 5, 1953, the official liquidator took out misfeasance proceedings under s. 235 of the Companies Act and the appellants then applied to the High Court for quashing the criminal proceedings

facts.text: Calcutta High Court refused leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal having been refused by the Calcutta High Court, the appellants have companye to this Court in pursuance of special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants have companye to this Court in pursuance of special leave. On the application of the official liquidator Bachawat J. an January 15, 1951, made an order which must be taken to be one under s. 179.

facts.text: Relevant facts were placed before the Company Judge in the report of Adhikary and affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberquestion in the present case that the relevant facts were all placed before the Company Judge, because they are all set out in the report of Adhikary and the affidavits annexed there to to which the order expressly refers

facts.text: High Court held that the order of Bannerji J. was under s.237(1).

anchor.surface_text: which the High Court has held, and in our opinion rightly, to be an order under s. 237 1  of the Indian Companies Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on September 11, 1958 by Kapur J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. September 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-This appeal by special leave raises a question of interpretation of s. 237 of the Indian Companies Act.

facts.text: Appellants' application to quash proceedings heard with rule issued on June 29, 1953 and dismissed on June 21, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This application was also heard with the rule which was issued on June 29, 1953, and it was dismissed by the same judgment by which the rule was discharged, i. e., of June 21, 1954.

facts.text: Ranadeb Chaudhury and P. K. Chatterjee appeared for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: 1264 Ranadeb Chaudhury and P. K. Chatterjee, for the appellants. Sen and P. K. Bose, for the respondents. 1958. September 11.

facts.text: Sen and P. K. Bose appeared for the respondents.

interpretation of s. 237 of the Indian Companies Act. Appellant No. 1 is One of the past directors of the Bank of Commerce Ltd., now in liquidation and appellant No. 2 was its Managing Director.

concepts.interpretation: Section does not make court direction a condition precedent for liquidator to institute prosecution; court may direct prosecution but liquidator can file complaint under s.179 without it; no prior hearing to accused required before direction.

issues.text: This appeal by special leave raises a question of interpretation of s. 237 of the Indian Companies Act

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises a question of interpretation of s. 237 of the Indian Companies Act. Appellant No. 1 is One of the past directors of the Bank of Commerce Ltd., now in liquidation and appellant No. 2 was its Managing Director.

issues.text: whether the prosecution was ab initio void because of the absence of prior direction judicially given by the High Court under s. 237(1) of the Indian Companies Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for quashing the criminal proceedings on the ground that the prosecution was ab initio void because of the absence of prior direction judicially given by the High Court under s. 237 1  of the Indian Companies Act. The High Court found against the appellants and discharged the rule.

issues.text: whether without the order of the Court the official liquidator cannot lodge a criminal complaint against a past director and if he does so the proceedings will be ab initio void

anchor.surface_text: It was this section which the appellants pressed in support of the argument that without the order of the Court the official liquidator cannot lodge a criminal complaint against a past director and if he does so the proceedings will be ab initio void. All that sub-s.  1  requires is that if the Court finds in- the course of winding up that any past or present director,

issues.text: whether directions under s.237(1) could be given by the judge unless the persons accused are first allowed an opportunity of giving an explanation

anchor.surface_text: But emphasis was placed by counsel for the appellants on the proviso that no prosecution could be undertaken without first giving the accused person an opportunity of making a statement in writing to the registrar and of being heard thereon and it was urged that if the registrar cannot institute prosecution without first giving an opportunity to the person accused to file an explanation,

issues.text: the official liquidator was not authorised to do anything either without the sanction of the Court or without its directions

anchor.surface_text: The general scheme of the Companies Act is that the Court should have complete control of all proceedings in winding up and it was therefore urged that the official liquidator was not authorised to do anything either without the sanction of the Court or without its directions. Section 179 deals with the powers of official liquidator.

issues.text: the appellants then applied to the High Court for quashing the criminal proceedings already started on the ground of commencement of proceedings under s. 235

anchor.surface_text: On August 5, 1953, the official liquidator took out misfeasance proceedings under s. 235 of the Companies Act and the appellants then applied to the High Court for quashing the criminal proceedings already started on the ground of commencement of proceedings under s. 235. This application was also heard with the rule which was issued on June 29, 1953,

anchor.surface_text: All that sub-s.  1  requires is that if the Court finds in- the course of winding up that any past or present director, the Court may either on the application of the person interested or of its own motion direct the liquidator to prosecute the offender or to refer the matter to the registrar.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the official liquidator Bachawat J. an January 15, 1951, made an order which must be taken to be one under s. 179.

arguments.claim: No sanction required under s.179 for commencing prosecution per precedents like Jaswantrai

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it has been held that under s. 179 of the Indian Companies Act no sanction is required for commencing a prosecution. In Jaswantrai Manilal Akhaney v. The State of Bombay

arguments.claim: s.237 lacks prohibitory words like CrPC ss.196/197 requiring prior sanction

anchor.surface_text: there are no words corresponding to the language of Drug Control Order... no are there any prohibitory words like those that are contained in ss. 196 and 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Liquidator complaint valid even absent s.237 direction; supports High Court cases like Emperor v. Bishan Sahai

anchor.surface_text: There are two cases decided by two Indian High Courts which support the submission of the respondents counsel. In Emperor v. Bishan Sahai it was held that the Companies Act nowhere provides that without the directions of a Judge no criminal prosecution can be instituted.

holdings.text: The order of Bannerji J dated July 22, 1952 is rightly an order under s.237(1) of the Indian Companies Act

anchor.surface_text: On July 22, 1952, the official liquidator obtained the order from Bannerji J. which the High Court has held, and in our opinion rightly, to be an order under s. 237 1  of the Indian Companies Act. This order said It is ordered

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly classified it as s.237(1) order; relevant facts from Adhikary report and affidavits were before the judge, showing application of mind

holdings.text: The order of Bachawat J dated January 15, 1951 must be taken to be one under s.179

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the official liquidator Bachawat J. an January 15, 1951, made an order which must be taken to be one under s. 179. In this order it was said And it is further ordered that the said applicant be at liberty

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order granted liberty to institute civil or criminal proceedings, aligning with powers under s.179(a)

holdings.text: s.237(1) does not require the court to give the offender an opportunity before directing the liquidator to prosecute

anchor.surface_text: Giving an opportunity to the offender before such direction is given by the Court is number a prerequisite of the Judge making in order under sub-s.  1 . Under sub-s.  6  the registrar is required to give the offender an opportunity to show cause before a prosecution is undertaken.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso in sub-s.(6) applies to registrar's prosecution, not prerequisite for court's direction under sub-s.(1); textual distinction between subsections

holdings.text: No sanction of the court is required under s.179 for the official liquidator to commence a prosecution

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it has been held that under s. 179 of the Indian Companies Act no sanction is required for commencing a prosecution. In Jaswantrai Manilal Akhaney v. The State of Bombay

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in Jaswantrai; s.179 empowers liquidator without imposing condition precedent on criminal courts, unlike CrPC ss.196/197

holdings.text: The complaint by the liquidator suffers from no infirmity making the proceedings null and void; s.237(1) direction not condition precedent

anchor.surface_text: It would thus appear that both on the language of s. 237 1  as well as on precedent the companyplaint made by the liquidator against the appellants suffers from numbersuch infirmity as to make the proceedings null and void. The section companytains numbersuch words

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.237(1) permissive (may direct), not mandatory; s.179 grants liquidator power; no prohibitory language; supported by High Court precedents like Emperor v. Bishan Sahai

holdings.text: Even in the absence of directions under s.237(1), the legality of criminal proceedings instituted by liquidator would not be affected

anchor.surface_text: As we have said above even in the absence of such directions the legality of the criminal proceedings instituted would number be affected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.179 independently empowers liquidator; s.237 concerns court powers only; no words barring prosecution without direction

anchor.surface_text: It would thus appear that both on the language of s. 237 1  as well as on precedent the companyplaint made by the liquidator against the appellants suffers from numbersuch infirmity as to make the proceedings null and void. The section companytains numbersuch words which indicate that such a prosecution cannot be instituted by a liquidator without the sanction of the Judge or that the Court cannot take companynizance of a companyplaint without such sanction or direction. Section 179 as the learned Chief Justice of Calcutta High Court has rightly pointed out, deals with the powers of liquidators to institute or defend proceedings with the sanction of the Court and s. 237 1  deals with the powers of the Court to give, directions.
